Free Subscription See the Current Issue Archived Issues Articles White Papers Products News Blogs 5-Minute Interviews Part Search Submit News and Products Automotive Industrial Industrial Hardware Industrial Software Industrial Networking Sensors and Control Human Interface Test & Measurement Smart Energy IoT Development Kit Selector Security Dev Tools and OS RTOS Virtualization Processing DSP IP Microcontroller Programmable Logic SoC ‚Ä¶More Hardware Boards Sensors Systems Development Kit Selector Networking Cloud Storage DIY Development Kit Selector Medical Military PLUS: Embedded TechCon Ray Zinn: Lessons from a Leader List of Authors RSS Events Calendar Reference Designs Dev Kit Selector Newsletters Embedded Daily IoT Design Weekly Embedded Europe E-newsletter Automotive Embedded Systems Monthly E-Letter Webcasts E-Letter 5G is paving the way for autonomous cars Majeed Ahmed, Automotive Contributor - Leave a Comment Is it merely a coincidence that both 5G and autonomous car projects share the common implementation time frames of the late 2010s and early 2020s? Yes, it is. But the fact that these two gigantic technology roadmaps are converging and colliding isn‚Äôt just a coincidence. 5G is helping automotive industry in dealing with the vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) conundrum that has long been shadowing the connected car promise: Who will pay for the roadside infrastructure? Automotive industry or governments? Now connected cars can utilize the 5G signals to scope out road and weather conditions and draw up more accurate maps. And for the vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication part, 5G frees up the automotive industry from the obligation of developing a specialized infrastructure based on the dedicated short-range communications (DSRC) technology. [Vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communications ‚Äî serving as the foundation of the connected car movement ‚Äî is also becoming a key enabling technology for the autonomous vehicles. Image courtesy of Qualcomm] The next frontier after getting cars fully connected is automated driving, a.k.a. autonomous cars. According to Intel‚Äôs CEO, Brian Krzanich, an autonomous car can generate as much as four terabytes of data in a day, so a robust and pervasive communications infrastructure is imperative in moving more data at higher speeds and lower latency with utmost reliability. The 5G network will help vehicles keep tabs on cars, cyclists, and pedestrians in the vicinity while serving as glue between the key building blocks of advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) and self-driving cars. In other words, it will facilitate split-second connectivity for cameras, radars, and other in-vehicle sensors providing the 360-degree view. Then, there are machine learning tasks for image and speech recognition that require faster and ultra-reliable data links along with greater compute power and data synthesization capabilities. The autonomous car brings forth massive data challenges, so 5G is most likely going to become part of the automated driving ecosystem by facilitating large chunks of data via roadside communication infrastructure. There isn‚Äôt much automotive connectivity in play right now, and many industry observers attribute this to the lack of automotive friendly features in the 4G LTE networks. The 5G systems claim to offer five times lower latencies than predecessor 4G networks while enabling the more intelligent use of the radio spectrum through software-defined networks (SDN), network slicing, and virtualization techniques. The creation of the 5G Automotive Association (5GAA) is clearly a harbinger of the convergence between mobility and connected automated driving. The multi-industry body is carrying out cross-sector collaboration to facilitate road safety and intelligent transportation for autonomous cars. Majeed Ahmad is former Editor-in-Chief of EE Times Asia. He is a journalist with an engineering background and two decades of experience in writing and editing technical content. He is also the author of six books on electronics: Smartphone, Nokia‚Äôs Smartphone Problem and The Next Web of 50 Billion Devices, Mobile Commerce 2.0, Age of Mobile Data, and Essential 4G Guide. Topics covered in this article autonomous cars Virtualization connected car automotive v2v lte Advertisement Embedded Computing Design Articles White Papers Products News Blogs 5-Minute Interviews Part Search ¬© MMXVII Embedded Computing Design An OpenSystems Media publication. SUBSCRIBE LOG IN LOG OUT REGISTER MY PROFILE Obituaries Events Jobs Real Estate Cars Classified PG Store April 29, 2017 3:02 AM 7-day Forecast Post-Gazette.com Archives Home News Local Sports Opinion A & E Life Business Contact Us Advertisement Pentagon joins intensifying probe of former Trump aide Flynn April 28, 2017 1:18 AM Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press In this Feb. 10 file photo, then-National Security Adviser Michael Flynn sits in the East Room of the White House in Washington, D.C. By Chad Day and Stephen Braun / Associated Press WASHINGTON ‚Äî Investigations intensified into President Donald Trump‚Äôs ousted national security adviser, Michael Flynn, on Thursday as the Pentagon watchdog joined lawmakers in probing payments he accepted from foreign sources including a Russian state-sponsored TV network. At the same time, documents released by the top Democrat on a House oversight committee showed Mr. Flynn was warned by authorities after he retired from the military in 2014 not to take foreign government-sourced money without ‚Äúadvance approval‚Äù from the Pentagon. Mr. Flynn, a former Army lieutenant general and Defense Intelligence Agency chief, later accepted tens of thousands of dollars for his work on behalf of foreign interests, including RT, the state-supported Russian television network, and a Turkish-owned company linked to Turkey‚Äôs government. The Pentagon‚Äôs acting inspector general‚Äôs office confirmed Thursday he has launched an inquiry into whether those payments qualify as coming from foreign governments and whether Mr. Flynn properly informed military authorities about them. The White House defended its hiring of Mr. Flynn and attempted to shift blame for any problems with his vetting onto the Obama administration, which handled the reissuance of his security clearance in January 2016. Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., who released the documents, said during a news conference that Mr. Flynn had been clearly informed he needed to get permission to receive foreign payments and there‚Äôs no evidence he did so. ‚ÄúThe Pentagon‚Äôs warning to Gen. Flynn was bold, italicized and could not have been clearer,‚Äù Mr. Cummings said. In a key 2014 document, Mr. Flynn was told by a Defense Intelligence Agency official that the U.S. Constitution‚Äôs emoluments provision prohibits any monetary payments or gifts ‚Äúfrom a foreign government unless congressional consent is first obtained.‚Äù The Oct. 8, 2014, letter ‚Äî which was sent to Mr. Flynn at his request ‚Äî explained that such ‚Äúadvance approval‚Äù would need to come ‚Äúfrom the relevant service secretary.‚Äù Earlier this week, Mr. Cummings and Republican Rep. Jason Chaffetz, chairman of the House committee, said that they had found no evidence Mr. Flynn asked the Army for permission to receive foreign payments or informed the military he had accepted them. Army spokeswoman Cynthia O. Smith said the Army had no records that Mr. Flynn requested that permission. One episode in question involves a trip he took to Moscow in 2015 for RT‚Äôs anniversary celebration. He was paid at least $33,750 to attend the gala at which he was seated next to Russian President Vladimir Putin. ‚ÄúGen. Flynn‚Äôs attorney says he discussed his trip to Moscow with DIA, but we have no evidence, not a shred, that he disclosed his payments,‚Äù Mr. Cummings said Thursday. In a statement, Mr. Flynn‚Äôs attorney Robert Kelner said the Defense Department ‚Äúwas fully aware of the trip,‚Äù citing his previous statements that his client briefed DIA officials before and after the RT trip. Mr. Kelner also pointed to a letter, released in redacted form by Mr. Cummings, that notes that Mr. Flynn provided a thumb drive to the agency containing documents detailing the RT event, including that Leading Authorities, a speakers bureau that handled Mr. Flynn‚Äôs paid speeches, was handling the event for him. Mr. Kelner‚Äôs statement did not address other payments Mr. Flynn received from foreign sources. Mr. Flynn has previously disclosed he got between $50,000 and $100,000 as part of his personal stake in $530,000 that his company, Flynn Intel Group, received for consulting work last year for a Turkish businessman. Last month Mr. Flynn‚Äôs firm filed as a foreign agent with the Justice Department for its consulting work and acknowledged the work may have benefited the government of Turkey. Mr. Flynn‚Äôs client, Inovo BV, is owned by a businessman who is also a member of a committee overseen by Turkey‚Äôs finance ministry. In comments to the AP, Utah Republican Mr. Chaffetz, chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, said that Mr. Flynn ‚Äúhad an obligation to seek approval to take money from a foreign government. We found no evidence that he did that.‚Äù Mr. Chaffetz‚Äôs office released a letter he sent on Thursday to the Army, asking the service‚Äôs acting secretary to make a final determination as to whether Mr. Flynn violated federal law by accepting the payments, and if so, to start the process of recovering that money. Mr. Chaffetz also asked the Army to say why it hasn‚Äôt yet made a determination as to the legality of Mr. Flynn‚Äôs payments from RT given that they have been widely reported for at least two years. He also wants the Army to disclose any other investigations it‚Äôs launched since 2010 into similar legal violations. The committee‚Äôs inquiry is one of several congressional investigations into Mr. Flynn‚Äôs contacts with foreign officials. Mr. Trump fired Mr. Flynn in February for failing to inform senior administration officials about his contacts with Russian officials ‚Äî contacts that are being examined as part of the wider inquiries into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential campaign. On Thursday, 18 House Democrats on the oversight committee signed a letter calling on Mr. Chaffetz to do more to pressure the White House to release documents regarding Mr. Flynn. ‚ÄúThere is obviously a paper trail that the White House does not want our committee to follow,‚Äù the Democrats wrote in the letter. On Thursday, White House press secretary Sean Spicer rebuffed criticism from Mr. Cummings that the White House was covering up. Asked about Trump administration vetting, Mr. Spicer appeared to shift blame onto the Obama administration, which had fired Mr. Flynn as head of the DIA. ‚ÄúWhy would you re-run a background check on someone who is the head of the Department of Defense Intelligence Agency that had and did maintain a high-level security clearance?‚Äù Mr. Spicer asked. He noted that Mr. Flynn‚Äôs security clearance was renewed during the Obama administration ‚Äúwith all of the information that‚Äôs being discussed that occurred in 2015.‚Äù The White House recently told the committee that documents the lawmakers sought would not be turned over because they contained classified information or were not relevant to the committee‚Äôs investigation. Senate confirms Acosta The Senate on Thursday confirmed Alex Acosta as Labor secretary, filling out Mr. Trump‚Äôs Cabinet. The 60-38 vote confirms Mr. Acosta ‚Äî the only Latino to join Mr. Trump‚Äôs Cabinet¬†‚Äî to the post. Once sworn as the nation‚Äôs 27th Labor secretary, the son of Cuban immigrants will lead a sprawling agency that enforces more than 180 federal laws covering about 10 million employers and 125 million workers. Sen. Tim Scott, R-S.C., spoke for many Republicans with a statement issued just after the vote saying he hopes Mr. Acosta‚Äôs focus will be ‚Äúpromoting labor policies that are free of unnecessarily burdensome federal regulations.‚Äù Mr. Scott said he wants Acosta to permanently revoke rules governing financial advisers and adding Americans eligible for overtime pay. Democrats said any Labor secretary should advocate for the American workers to whom Mr. Trump promised so much during his upstart presidential campaign. They said Mr. Acosta has given no such commitment. Labor secretary is the last Cabinet post for Mr. Trump to fill. Mr. Trump‚Äôs choice for U.S. trade representative, a job considered Cabinet-level, is awaiting a Senate vote. Tax overhaul push A senior administration official speaking anonymously said Thursday the White House plans to push its tax overhaul without any support from congressional Democrats. Meanwhile, asked on ‚ÄúGood Morning America‚Äù on Thursday whether everyone in the middle class would see their taxes reduced, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin admitted that it‚Äôs possible they won‚Äôt. New office at VA Mr. Trump on Thursday created an office at the Department of Veterans Affairs to improve accountability and protect whistle-blowers, calling it a ‚Äúbold step forward.‚Äù March for climate Thousands of environmentalists will once again rally in the nation‚Äôs capital this weekend, this time for the People‚Äôs Climate March. Coal¬†pollution case The Trump administration has successfully delayed a legal fight over enforcing Obama-era restrictions on pollution from coal-fired power plants. The Washington Post and¬†McClatchy Newspapers contributed.
